CreditLine: Promised gift of John and Berthe Ford
Description: The sun god, who is both Hindu and Buddhist, appears at the center, flanked by Dawn and Pre-Dawn; the next circle holds the planets; and the outer circle has the twelve forms of the sun. Across the top, two bodhisattvas flank the five cosmic Buddhas. On the bottom, at the left, the priest presents offerings to a fire; on the right are the patron and his family. Nepalese Buddhists carried out ceremonies intended to prevent evil influences from disturbing the sun and the moon. The sun may also be an object of meditation, paired with the moon and imagined inside one's body.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Santa Barbara Museum of Art, Santa Barbara; Albuquerque Museum, Albuquerque; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham. 2001-2003.

Provenance: George Subkoff Antiquities, New York [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; John and Berthe Ford, Baltimore, June 22, 1981, by purchase.
Title: Mandala of the Sun God
